maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new element to the specified parent.
Adds a new element to the specified parent. This will add the element after existing children.

maml:Description.maml:para: Add the element to all connected clients. If you don't specify this Switch, the element will only be added to whoever is interacting with the website.
The content to append to the parent element.
The ID of the parent element.
Add the element to all connected clients. If you don't specify this Switch, the element will only be added to whoever is interacting with the website.
The content to append to the parent element.
The ID of the parent element.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a message element the "chatroom" parent element. It will add this element to all connected clients.

maml:description.maml:para: Clears the Universal Dashboard cache scope.
Clears the Universal Dashboard cache scope. Existing $Cache variables will no longer be present.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Clear-UDCache

dev:remarks.maml:para: Clears the UD cache.

maml:description.maml:para: Clears the children of the specified element.
Clears the children of the specified element.

maml:Description.maml:para: Add the element to all connected clients. If you don't specify this Switch, the element will only be added to whoever is interacting with the website.
The ID of the element to clear.
Add the element to all connected clients. If you don't specify this Switch, the element will only be added to whoever is interacting with the website.
The ID of the element to clear.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Clear-UDElement -Id "chatroom"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Clears the chatroom element of all children.

maml:description.maml:para: Disables logging for Universal Dashboard.
Disables logging for Universal Dashboard.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Disable-UDLogging

dev:remarks.maml:para: Disables logging for Universal Dashboard.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables logging for Universal Dashboard.
Enables logging for Universal Dashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: Logs to the console.
Logs to the specified file.
The log level to log. Will log the level specified and above.
Logs to the console.
Logs to the specified file.
The log level to log. Will log the level specified and above.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Enable-UDLogging -Level Debug -FilePath .\log.txt -Console

dev:remarks.maml:para: Outputs Debug messages and above to the log.txt file and the console.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the content-type of an HTTP request.
Returns the content-type of an HTTP request. This cmdlet should be used within Endpoint script blocks.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-UDContentType

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the content-type of the HTTP request.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a cookie from the HTTP request.
Gets a cookie from the HTTP request. This cmdlet should be called within endpoints.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the cookie to return.
The name of the cookie to return.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the value of MyCookie as a Toast when the user clicks the submit button.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns dashboards started with Start-UDDashboard.
Returns dashboards started with Start-UDDashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the dashboard.
The name of the dashboard.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-UDDashboard

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all dashboards stared with Start-UDDashboard.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-UDDashboard -Name "MyDashboard"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns a dashboard named "MyDashboard" started with Start-UDDashboard.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns an element from the client.
Returns an element from the client. This cmdlet can be used to return changes in state, like the value of a text box.

maml:Description.maml:para: The ID of the element to get.
The ID of the element to get.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $txtMessage = Get-UDElement -Id "message" PS C:\> $Message = "$(Get-Date) $User : $($txtMessage.Attributes['value'])"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the "message" element from the client and gets the value of the text box and formats it into the message string.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the installed license
Gets the installed license

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-License

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the installed license

maml:description.maml:para: Returns all running REST API servers.
Returns all running REST API servers.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the REST API server to return.
The name of the REST API server to return.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-UDRestApi -Name "RestApi1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the REST API server named RestApi1.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the pre-defined themes for Universal Dashboard.
Returns the pre-defined themes for Universal Dashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the theme to return.
The name of the theme to return.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Themes = Get-UDTheme

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all the themes for Universal Dashboard.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Theme = Get-UDTheme -Name 'Azure'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the Azure theme for Universal Dashboard.

maml:description.maml:para: Grants a JSON web token for the specified user or application.
Grants a JSON web token for the specified user. You can adjust the JSON web token parameters in addition to specifying the user.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the application granted the token.
The aud (audience) claim identifies the recipients that the JWT is intended for. See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.3
The exp (expiration time) claim identifies the expiration time on or after which the JWT MUST NOT be accepted for processing.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.4
The iss (issuer) claim identifies the principal that issued the JWT.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.1
The secret key used to sign the web token. This should be treated as a password.
The sub (subject) claim identifies the principal that is the subject of the JWT.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.2
The aud (audience) claim identifies the recipients that the JWT is intended for. See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.3
The exp (expiration time) claim identifies the expiration time on or after which the JWT MUST NOT be accepted for processing.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.4
The iss (issuer) claim identifies the principal that issued the JWT.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.1
The secret key used to sign the web token. This should be treated as a password.
The sub (subject) claim identifies the principal that is the subject of the JWT.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.2
The user name of the user the token is granted to.
The name of the application granted the token.
The aud (audience) claim identifies the recipients that the JWT is intended for. See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.3
The exp (expiration time) claim identifies the expiration time on or after which the JWT MUST NOT be accepted for processing.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.4
The iss (issuer) claim identifies the principal that issued the JWT.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.1
The secret key used to sign the web token. This should be treated as a password.
The sub (subject) claim identifies the principal that is the subject of the JWT.
See: https://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html#rfc.section.4.1.2
The user name of the user the token is granted to.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Token = Grant-UDJsonWebToken -UserName "Adam" PS C:\> Invoke-RestMethod http://localhost/api/resource -Headers @{ Authorization = "Bearer $Token"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a JSON web token for Adam and then uses that token to access a protected resource on the API.

maml:description.maml:para: Hides a modal shown with Show-UDModal.
Hides a modal shown with Show-UDModal.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Hide-UDModal

maml:description.maml:para: Hides a toast message.
Hides a toast mesage.

maml:Description.maml:para: The ID of the toast message to hide.
The ID of the toast message to hide.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Hide-UDToast -Id "ToastMessage"

maml:description.maml:para: Performs a clientside "click" event on the specified id, if the element is clickable.
Performs a clientside "click" event on the specified id, if the element is clickable.

maml:Description.maml:para: The id of the event to trigger.
The typeof event to trigger
The id of the event to trigger.
The typeof event to trigger

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-UDEvent -id "someid" -event "onClick"

maml:description.maml:para: Execute javascript on client.
Executes specified javascript on the client.

maml:Description.maml:para: The javascript "codeblock" in string format.
The javascript "codeblock" in string format.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-UDJavaScript -JavaScript 'alert("hello world");'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Executes the "alert" function of Javascript on the client, and alerts the user with "hello world".

The y-Axis for this chart. Use New-UDCategoryChartAxis, New-UDLinearChartAxis or New-UDLogarithmicChartAxis.
Percent (0-1) of the available width each bar should be within the category width. 1.0 will take the whole category width and put the bars right next to each other.
Percent (0-1) of the available width each category should be within the sample width.

### -IconAlignment The icon alignment.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases: Accepted values: left, right
Required: False Position: 4 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Id The ID of the component.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 0 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -OnClick An event handler that is called when the button is clicked. This can be either a ScriptBlock or a UDEndpoint.
```yaml Type: Object Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 2 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Height Sets the height, either by pixel or percentage.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Width Sets the width, either by pixel or percentage.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Style Sets the style of the button, will be prioritized over the other stylespecific parameters, ie -height.
```yaml Type: Hashtable Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Text The test to display on the button.
```yaml Type: Object Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 1 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ Raised Button ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDButton -Text "Button"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a basic, raised button.

command:example.maml:title: ----------------------- Button with Icon -----------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDButton -Text "Button" -Icon cloud

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a basic, raised button with an icon.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ Button Colors ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDButton -Text "Button" -BackgroundColor "red" -FontColor "white"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a red button with white text.

command:example.maml:title: --------------------------- Floating ---------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDButton -Floating -Icon plus

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a circular, floating button with a plus icon.

command:example.maml:title: ----------------------------- Flat -----------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDButton -Flat -Text "Button"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a flat button

command:example.maml:title: -------------------- OnClick Event Handler --------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creats a button that shows a toast message when clicked.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------- Button sizes -------------------------
command:example.dev:code: ` New-UDButton -Text "Big" -Height 300 -Width "100%"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a button with height of 300px and 100% width. Note: the "px" will be appended automatically if not specified.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------ Custom styles ------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a button, with font-size 36 and height of 300 pixels. Will be prioritized over the -height param.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Basic Card --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDCard -Title "Details" -Text "These are some details about my dashboard" -Links @(New-UDLink -Url http://www.google.com -Text "Google a little more info")

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new card with a title, some text and a link.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Image Card --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a card with an image.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------- Reveal Card -------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a card that you can click to reveal more information.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates options for a category chart axis. Used with chart options.
Creates options for a category chart axis. Used with chart options.

maml:Description.maml:para: Position of the axis in the chart. Possible values are: 'top', 'left', 'bottom', 'right'
If true, extra space is added to the both edges and the axis is scaled to fit into the chart area. This is set to true in the bar chart by default.
The ID of the axis. This can should be referenced with the dataset using the axis.
An array of labels to display.
The minimum item to display.
The maximum item to display.
The ID of the axis. This can should be referenced with the dataset using the axis.
An array of labels to display.
The maximum item to display.
The minimum item to display.
If true, extra space is added to the both edges and the axis is scaled to fit into the chart area. This is set to true in the bar chart by default.
Position of the axis in the chart. Possible values are: 'top', 'left', 'bottom', 'right'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-UDCategoryChartAxis -Labels @('January', 'February', 'March', 'April', 'May', 'June')

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a category chart axis with labels for January, February, March, April, May and June.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new chart.
Creates a new chart on the dashboard. Chart data is provided via a PowerShell endpoint. This cmdlet is paired with Out-UDChartData and New-UDChartDataset to provide the data for display to the chart.

maml:Description.maml:para: Arguments to pass to to the endpoint.
Enables auto refresh for this component.
Background color of the chart control.
The endpoint that is called on the server to get data for the chart. Use Out-UDChartData and optionally, New-UDChartDataset to format data to return correctly from the endpoint.
Input controls to adjust chart data. Use New-UDInputField to create fields for this script block.
Font color of the chart control.
Set monitor custom height, you can use px,vw,% You can NOT use this parameter without width parameter. If you do you will get an error.
The ID of the chart. This ID is set on the HTML markup and is also used to identify the endpoint.
Specifies labels to be used for the chart data. This is used instead of the LabelProperty of New-UDChartData.
Links to display on the bottom of the chart. Use New-UDLink to generate a link.
{{Fill OnClick Description}}
ChartJS options to pass. This is a hashtable of options and should match the format of ChartJS options. See http://www.chartjs.org/docs/latest/ for more information.
The number of seconds between auto refreshes. This defauts to 5 seconds.
The title of the section containing the chart.
The type of chart to display.
Set monitor custom width, you can use px,vw,% You can use only width without the height parameter.
Arguments to pass to to the endpoint.
Enables auto refresh for this component.
Background color of the chart control.
The endpoint that is called on the server to get data for the chart. Use Out-UDChartData and optionally, New-UDChartDataset to format data to return correctly from the endpoint.
Input controls to adjust chart data. Use New-UDInputField to create fields for this script block.
Font color of the chart control.
Set monitor custom height, you can use px,vw,% You can NOT use this parameter without width parameter. If you do you will get an error.
The ID of the chart. This ID is set on the HTML markup and is also used to identify the endpoint.
Specifies labels to be used for the chart data. This is used instead of the LabelProperty of New-UDChartData.
Links to display on the bottom of the chart. Use New-UDLink to generate a link.
{{Fill OnClick Description}}
ChartJS options to pass. This is a hashtable of options and should match the format of ChartJS options. See http://www.chartjs.org/docs/latest/ for more information.
The number of seconds between auto refreshes. This defauts to 5 seconds.
The title of the section containing the chart.
The type of chart to display.
Set monitor custom width, you can use px,vw,% You can use only width without the height parameter.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------- Simple Chart -------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a simple bar chart with information about the CPU usage of all the chrome processes running on the current machine.

command:example.maml:title: --------------------- Multi-dataset Chart ---------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a bar chart with multiple data sets displaying different types of memory usage. Each data set is colored and labeled differently.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a dataset for use with Out-UDChartData
Creates a dataset for use with Out-UDChartData. This is an advanced scenario cmdlet that allows you to create multiple datasets within a single chart.

maml:Description.maml:para: The property to select as the data for the y value of the chart.
A label of this dataset.

Additional options to pass to the dataset. This value can be different depending on the type of chart specified. See the ChartJS documentation for more information. http://www.chartjs.org/docs/latest/charts/line.html
The background color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The border color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The width of the border in pixels.
The hover background color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The hover border color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The hover width of the border in pixels.
The ID of the X axis. Used for advanced properties.
The ID of the Y axis. Used for advanced properties.

Additional options to pass to the dataset. This value can be different depending on the type of chart specified. See the ChartJS documentation for more information. http://www.chartjs.org/docs/latest/charts/line.html
The background color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The border color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The width of the border in pixels.
The property to select as the data for the y value of the chart.
The hover background color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The hover border color of the dataset in the chart. Should be in rgba() syntax.
The hover width of the border in pixels.
A label of this dataset.
The ID of the X axis. Used for advanced properties.
The ID of the Y axis. Used for advanced properties.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a chart with different datasets of different types of memory usage.

The padding to add inside the chart.
The padding to add inside the bottom of the chart.
The padding to add inside the left of the chart.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $LayoutOptions = New-UDLayoutOptions -Padding 15 PS C:\> $Options = New-UDChartOptions -LayoutOptions $LayoutOptions

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates chart options with layout options set to a padding for 15.

maml:description.maml:para: Legend options for a chart.
Legend options for a chart.

maml:Description.maml:para: Position of the legend.
Marks that this box should take the full width of the canvas (pushing down other boxes). This is unlikely to need to be changed in day-to-day use.
width of coloured box
font size of text
font style of text
Font family of legend text.
Padding between rows of colored boxes.
Label style will match corresponding point style (size is based on fontSize, boxWidth is not used in this case).
Hides the legend.
Legend will show datasets in reverse order.

font size of text
font style of text

Position of the legend.
Legend will show datasets in reverse order.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $LegendOptions = New-UDChartLegendOptions -Position "bottom" PS C:\> $Options = New-UDChartOptions -LegendOptions $LegendOptions

dev:remarks.maml:para: Moves the legend to the bottom of the chart.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new collapsible.
Creates a new collapsible. Collapsibles are accordion elements that expand when clicked on. They allow you to hide content that is not immediately relevant to the user.

maml:Description.maml:para: The collapsible items to show in this collapsible. Use New-UDCollapsibleItem to create these items.
The background color of the collapsible.
The font color of the collapsible.
The ID of this component.
The collapsible behaves as a popout rather than sliding.
Defines whether multiple items can be expanded.
The background color of the collapsible.
The font color of the collapsible.
The ID of this component.
The collapsible items to show in this collapsible. Use New-UDCollapsibleItem to create these items.
The collapsible behaves as a popout rather than sliding.
Defines whether multiple items can be expanded.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------- Collapsible -------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new collapsible with 3 different items.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a collapsible item.
Creates a collapsible item. Use with New-UDCollapsible. This will create a single item within the collapsible.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies whether the item is active by default. This will expand the item.
Specifies that this component auto-refreshs on the RefreshInterval.
Background color of the component item.
The endpoint that returns the content for this component.
Font color of the component item.
Specifies whether the item is active by default. This will expand the item.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a collection of 3 items.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new column in the dashboard. This should be called within a New-UDRow's content or endpoint block.

Creates a new column in the dashboard. This should be called within a New-UDRow. Columns can be size 1-12. Size 12 would span the entire width of the page. If you had 12 size 1 columns, each would take up 1/12 of the page and they would be equally spaced along the row.

maml:Description.maml:para: Whether this column should auto-refresh. The default interval is every 5 seconds.
The endpoint to call to generate the content of this column. This is mutually exclusive with Content.
The ID of the column. This is the ID set in the HTML markup.
The number of columns to offset this column on large screens. Large screens are over 992px wide.
The size of this column on large screens. Large screens are over 992px wide.
The number of columns to offset this column on medium screens. Medium screens are over 600px and less than 992px wide.
The size of this column on medium screens. Medium screens are over 600px and less than 992px wide.
How often this column refreshes.
The number of columns to offset this column on small screens. Small screens are under 600px wide.
The size of this column on small screens. Small screens are under 600px wide.
The content of the column. This can be one or more controls. It can also be other another row of columns.
The ID of the column. This is the ID set in the HTML markup.
The number of columns to offset this column on large screens. Large screens are over 992px wide.
The size of this column on large screens. Large screens are over 992px wide.
The number of columns to offset this column on medium screens. Medium screens are over 600px and less than 992px wide.
The size of this column on medium screens. Medium screens are over 600px and less than 992px wide.
The number of columns to offset this column on small screens. Small screens are under 600px wide.
The size of this column on small screens. Small screens are under 600px wide.
Whether this column should auto-refresh. The default interval is every 5 seconds.
The content of the column. This can be one or more controls. It can also be other another row of columns.
The endpoint to call to generate the content of this column. This is mutually exclusive with Content.
The ID of the column. This is the ID set in the HTML markup.

The size of this column on medium screens. Medium screens are over 600px and less than 992px wide.

The size of this column on small screens. Small screens are under 600px wide.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creats a new row with a column that spans the entire page.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new row with 3 columns that take up 1/3 of the page width each.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a simple counter.
Creates a simple counter. The counter number can be formatted using Numeral formats. An icon can also be displayed with the Icon property.

maml:Description.maml:para: Arguments to pass to the endpoint. They will be available via the $ArgumentList variable.
Enables auto refresh for this component.
Background color of the panel.
The endpoint that is called on the server to get data for the counter. The data should be piped to ConvertTo-Json before returning from this cmdlet.
The font color.
The Numeral.js format for the counter. See http://numeraljs.com/ for more information.

command:example.maml:title: --------------------------- Counter ---------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Outputs a random number as a counter. Formats the number into KB, MB or TB depending on the size of the number returned. Puts the cloud_download icon in the background.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new dashboard. The result of this cmdlet should be passed to Start-UDDashboard.
Creates a new dashboard. The result of this cmdlet should be passed to Start-UDDashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: Background color.
Content of the dashboard.
Changes pages in the dashboard automatically.
The number of seconds to wait on each page before changing to the next page. Defaults to 10 seconds.
The initial session state for endpoints of this dashboard. Use New-UDEndpointInitialization to create an object for this parameter.
Font color.
Configuration options for the footer. Use New-UDFooter to create the object for these options.

Enables GeoLocation support for the dashboard. A $Location variable will be defined in all endpoints when this is enabled. When a user allows the dashboard to get their location, you will have access to the latitude, longitude, heading and speed.
The amount of time a session can be idle before it times out. This defaults to 25 minutes.
Navigation bar and footer color.
Navigation bar and footer font color.
A logo to use within the navbar. Use New-UDImage to create this logo.
Links to present on the dashboard. Use New-UDLink to create links.
{{Fill Navigation Description}}
Additional scripts to include with the dashboard. These scripts are not copied but just referenced in the output HTML.
Additional stylesheets to include with the dashboard. These stylesheets are not copied but just referenced in the output HTML.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new REST API endpoint.
Creates a new REST API endpoint. This can be used with Start-UDDashboard nad Start-UDRestApi. All URLs are automatically prefixed with /api.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enabled uploading files to this REST API endpoint.
Arguments to pass to the endpoint. They will be available via the $ArgumentList variable.
The script block endpoint that is invoked when the URL is called. This script block can provide a param block with arguments that will be passed in from the URL or the body of the request.
{{Fill EvaluateUrlAsRegex Description}}
The ID of ths endpoint.
The HTTP method for this endpoint.

The URL for this endpoint. All URLs are automatically prefixed with "/api/". Any portion of the URL that starts with a colon ":", will be treated as a varied and can be accessed in the endpoint script block.
Arguments to pass to the endpoint. They will be available via the $ArgumentList variable.
The script block endpoint that is invoked when the URL is called. This script block can provide a param block with arguments that will be passed in from the URL or the body of the request.
The ID of ths endpoint.
Schedule to run this endpoint on. Use New-UDEndpointSchedule to create a schedule. Pass the endpoint to Start-UDDashboard.
Enabled uploading files to this REST API endpoint.
Arguments to pass to the endpoint. They will be available via the $ArgumentList variable.
The script block endpoint that is invoked when the URL is called. This script block can provide a param block with arguments that will be passed in from the URL or the body of the request.
{{Fill EvaluateUrlAsRegex Description}}
The ID of ths endpoint.
The HTTP method for this endpoint.
Schedule to run this endpoint on. Use New-UDEndpointSchedule to create a schedule. Pass the endpoint to Start-UDDashboard.

The URL for this endpoint. All URLs are automatically prefixed with "/api/". Any portion of the URL that starts with a colon ":", will be treated as a varied and can be accessed in the endpoint script block.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new REST API endpoint with a URL of "/api/user" that returns Adam, Sarah and Bill as a JSON array.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a REST API endpoint that stops the process with the ID specified in the URL. You could invoke this endpoint by calling /api/process/1234.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a REST API endpoint that accepts a HTTP POST with a name parameter in the body. Then it starts the server and invokes the endpoint with Invoke-RestMethod.

maml:description.maml:para: New-UDEndpointInitialization is used to configure the runspaces that Universal Dashboard uses to run Endpoints.

New-UDEndpointInitialization is used to configure the runspaces that Universal Dashboard uses to run Endpoints. The cmdlet creates a InitialSessionState object to automatically import variables, functions and modules. You can further customize this object to using the properties and methdos of the InitialSessionState class.
For more information, visit: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.management.automation.runspaces.initialsessionstate?view=powershellsdk-1.1.0

maml:Description.maml:para: Functions to import by default into the runspaces used for endpoints.
Modules to import by default into the runspaces used for endpoints.
Variables to import by default into the runspaces used for endpoints.
Functions to import by default into the runspaces used for endpoints.
Modules to import by default into the runspaces used for endpoints.
Variables to import by default into the runspaces used for endpoints.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $MyVariable = "Test" PS C:\> $EI = New-UDEndpointInitialization -Variable "MyVariable" PS C:\> $Dashboard = New-UDDashboard -Title "EI" -Content {} -EndpointInitialization $EI

dev:remarks.maml:para: Initializes the runspaces with the $MyVariable variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $MyVariable = "Test" PS C:\> $MyOtherVariable = "Test2" PS C:\> $EI = New-UDEndpointInitialization -Variable @("MyVariable", "MyOtherVariable") PS C:\> $Dashboard = New-UDDashboard -Title "EI" -Content {} -EndpointInitialization $EI

dev:remarks.maml:para: Initializes the runspaces with the $MyVariable and $MyOtherVariable variables.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Initializes the runspaces with the Get-Stuff function.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $EI = New-UDEndpointInitialization -Module "HyperV" PS C:\> $Dashboard = New-UDDashboard -Title "EI" -Content {} -EndpointInitialization $EI

dev:remarks.maml:para: Initializes the runspaces with the HyperV module.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $EI = New-UDEndpointInitialization PS C:\> $EI.StartupScripts.Add("C:\test.ps1") PS C:\> $Dashboard = New-UDDashboard -Title "EI" -Content {} -EndpointInitialization $EI

dev:remarks.maml:para: Initializes the runspaces with a startup script.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a schedule for an endpoint.

maml:Description.maml:para: Disables concurrently running this schedule. Ie, it does not allow the schedule to run multiple instances.
A CRON expression to run the schedule under.
Disables concurrently running this schedule. Ie, it does not allow the schedule to run multiple instances.
Switches the Every value to days.
Number of time units.
If set to 0 this means repeat forever, if not set it will also repeat forever. Otherwise it will run the schedule x amount of times.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a grid in the dashboard.

The title of the section for this grid.
Text to override the "Filter" placeholder text.
The endpoint that returns the grid data.
Arguments to pass to the endpoint. They will be available via the $ArgumentList variable.
The number of seconds between refreshes. The default is 5.
The headers to use for the grid columns. The count of headers should match the count of properties.
The properties to select from objects for data in the row. The number of properties should match the number of headers.
Specifies the column index of the default sort column. This index begins with zero.

Enables auto refresh for this control.
Specifies whether to sort descending or ascending by default.
Removes the export button from the grid.
Removes the filter text box from the grid.
Disables paging for this grid.
Turns on server side processing for the grid. This disables client-side filtering, sort and paging.

### -Inverse {{Fill Inverse Description}}

Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -ListItem {{Fill ListItem Description}}

### -Pull {{Fill Pull Description}}
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases: Accepted values: right, left
Required: False Position: 6 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Pulse Use this to have the icon to rotate with 8 steps
```yaml Type: SwitchParameter Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Regular This switch if define will search the icon in the FontAwesome regular pack, if the icon is not in the regular pack the command will used the fallback icon in the solid pack.
```yaml Type: SwitchParameter Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Rotation Wil rotate the icon by 90 degress
```yaml Type: Int32 Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 2 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Size Set the size of the icon
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases: Accepted values: xs, sm, lg, 2x, 3x, 4x, 5x, 6x, 7x, 8x, 9x, 10x
Required: False Position: 7 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Spin Will spin the icon like loading animation
```yaml Type: SwitchParameter Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Style Set css attributes on the icon like color etc...
```yaml Type: Hashtable Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 8 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Title {{Fill Title Description}}
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 9 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```

### -Transform Thanks to the power of SVG in Font Awesome 5, you can scale, position, flip, & rotate icons arbitrarily using the data-fa-transform element attribute. You can even combine them for some super-useful effects.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 4 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDIcon -Icon box -Style @{color = '#000'} -Id 'test-icon-button'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create icon with the default size sm and it has black color.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDIcon -Icon spinner -Size 3x -Style @{color = '#000'} -Id 'test-icon-button' -Spin

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create icon that has spin animation.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDIcon -Icon angry -Size 3x -Style @{color = '#000'} -Id 'test-icon-button' -Regular

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create angry icon that have a size of 3 and black color, and also this icon is from the FontAwesome regular pack ( semi light ) style.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an input card on the dashboard to accept user input.
Creates an input card on the dashboard to accept user input. The fields for the input are defined by the param block of the endpoint.

maml:Description.maml:para: Arguments to pass to the Endpoint parameter. They are available via the $ArgumentList variable within the endpoint.
The background color of the card.

Specify custom content for a UDInput. If this is specified, the param block in the Endpoint is not used to generate the controls in the input form. This provides additional control over which components show up and what values they posses. Used New-UDInputField to create a new input field.
The endpoint that will be executed when the form is submitted. A param block is requried.
The font coplor of the card.
The ID of the input control.
The text for the submit button. Defaults to Submit.
The title of the input card.
Whether or not to enforce client side validation via ValidationAttributes.

maml:description.maml:para: The linear scale is use to chart numerical data. It can be placed on either the x or y axis. The scatter chart type automatically configures a line chart to use one of these scales for the x axis. As the name suggests, linear interpolation is used to determine where a value lies on the axis.

The linear scale is use to chart numerical data. It can be placed on either the x or y axis. The scatter chart type automatically configures a line chart to use one of these scales for the x axis. As the name suggests, linear interpolation is used to determine where a value lies on the axis.

maml:Description.maml:para: Position of the axis in the chart.

maml:description.maml:para: The logarithmic scale is use to chart numerical data. It can be placed on either the x or y axis. As the name suggests, logarithmic interpolation is used to determine where a value lies on the axis.
The logarithmic scale is use to chart numerical data. It can be placed on either the x or y axis. As the name suggests, logarithmic interpolation is used to determine where a value lies on the axis.

maml:Description.maml:para: Position of the axis in the chart.
If true, extra space is added to the both edges and the axis is scaled to fit into the chart area. This is set to true in the bar chart by default.
The ID is used to link datasets and scale axes together.
User defined minimum number for the scale, overrides minimum value from data.
User defined maximum number for the scale, overrides maximum value from data.
The ID is used to link datasets and scale axes together.
User defined maximum number for the scale, overrides maximum value from data.
User defined minimum number for the scale, overrides minimum value from data.
If true, extra space is added to the both edges and the axis is scaled to fit into the chart area. This is set to true in the bar chart by default.
Position of the axis in the chart.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new login page.
Creates a new login page. This enables authentication for a dashboard. This cmdlet is used in conjunction with New-UDDashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: An array of authentication methods to use.
Text to display after the user clicks the login button. This is useful for login proceses that may take a second or notifying users of other actions they may need to take.
Color of the login form background.
Login form font color.
An image used as a logo on the login page. Use New-UDImage to generate this logo.
The login page background color.
Text to display above the login.
An array of authentication methods to use.
Text to display after the user clicks the login button. This is useful for login proceses that may take a second or notifying users of other actions they may need to take.
Color of the login form background.
Login form font color.
An image used as a logo on the login page. Use New-UDImage to generate this logo.
The login page background color.
Text to display above the login.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $LoginPage = New-UDLoginPage -AuthenticationMethod $AuthenticationMethod

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new login page with authentication methods.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a live updating chart that shows a single type of data on a running time scale.
Creates a live updating chart that shows a single type of data. This is paired with Out-UDMonitorData to output data on a running time scale.

maml:Description.maml:para: Arguments to pass to the endpoint. They will be available via the $ArgumentList variable.
Whether to auto refresh this component. This is on by default for this control.
The background color of the component containing the chart.
The border width for the chart.
Background fill color of the chart.
Order color of the chart.
The number of data points to keep in the history.
The endpoint definition for this chart. The endpoint should return a single data value via the Out-UDMonitorData cmdlet.
Input controls to adjust chart data. Use New-UDInputField to create fields for this script block.
Font color
Set monitor custom height, you can use px,vw,% You can NOT use this parameter without width parameter. If you do you will get an error.
The HTML ID and endpoint ID for this component.
A list of labels to use when defining multiple datasets. If this isn't specified, the Title is used.
Links to display on the bottom of the monitor. Use New-UDLink to generate a link.
The refresh interval for this control. This defaults to 5 seconds.
The title of this chart.
The type of chart to use.
Set monitor custom width, you can use px,vw,% You can use only width without the height parameter.

### -Id The ID of the page.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Name The name of the page. This will also become the URL of the page.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: name Aliases:
Required: True Position: 0 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -RefreshInterval The refresh interval, in seconds, for this page.
```yaml Type: Int32 Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: Named Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Title {{Fill Title Description}}
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: (All) Aliases:
Required: False Position: 4 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```
### -Url The URL for this page. You can include variables in your path by prefixing the section with a colon. See examples for usage scenario.
```yaml Type: String Parameter Sets: url Aliases:
Required: True Position: 0 Default value: None Accept pipeline input: False Accept wildcard characters: False ```

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a multi-page dashboard. The will show a navigation pane on the left side of the dashboard to navigate to different pages.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a multi-page dashboard. The will show a navigation pane on the left side of the dashboard to navigate to different pages. The URL for the cards page is /cards-page.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a multi-page dashboard. The will show a navigation pane on the left side of the dashboard to navigate to different pages. The URL for the cards page is /cards-page/:username. The :username portion of the URL can be replaced with any string. The variable $username will be available in the endpoint that generates the page.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a multi-page dashboard. The will show a navigation pane on the left side of the dashboard to navigate to different pages. The default home page will be Demo and NOT home. The dashboard title will also be linked to the default home page.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a radio.
Creates a radio. Radios can be used to select between a set of items. They should be grouped together.

maml:Description.maml:para: The ID for this radio.
The label for this radio.
A script block to invoke when this radio is changed. The event data will be available via the $EventData variable in the script block.

Whether this radio is disabled.
Provides a gap style for the radio button.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------- Basic Radio -------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDRadio -Label 'Option 1' -Group 'Group 1' New-UDRadio -Label 'Option 2' -Group 'Group 1' New-UDRadio -Label 'Option 3' -Group 'Group 1'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates three options for a radio group.

command:example.maml:title: --------------------------- OnChange ---------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates three options for a radio group with onChange event handlers.

New-UDRadio -Label 'Option 1' -Group 'Group 2' New-UDRadio -Label 'Option 2' -Group 'Group 2' New-UDRadio -Label 'Option 3' -Group 'Group 2'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates three options for two radio groups.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------- Basic Switch -------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDSwitch -OnText "yes" -OffText "No"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a switch that has yes and no as options.

command:example.maml:title: --------------------------- OnChange ---------------------------
command:example.dev:code: New-UDSwitch -OnText "yes" -OffText "No" -OnChange { Show-UDToast -Message $EventData }

dev:remarks.maml:para: Shows a toast when the switch is changed.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a tab container.

maml:Description.maml:para: ID of this component.
Only render tabs when active.
The tabs for this container. Use New-UDTab to create the tabs.
ID of this component.
Only render tabs when active.
The tabs for this container. Use New-UDTab to create the tabs.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Basic Tabs --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a tab container with 3 tabs.

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Tabs only rendered when active. ---------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: On renders a tab when the tab is the active tab. If the tab isn't active, the content isn't renderd. This helps with the performance of dashboards.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------------- Dynamic Tabs -------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a tab container with 3 tabs and tab content is dynamic.

command:example.maml:title: ------------------- Tabs with icons and text -------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a tab container with 3 tabs and icons.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Tabs with icons and text in stacked position ---------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a tab container with 3 tabs and icons.

command:example.maml:title: --------------------- Tabs with icons only ---------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a tab container with 3 tabs and icons only no labels.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new table of data within the dashboard.
Creates a new table of data within the dashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: Pass arguments to Endpoints.
Enabled auto refresh for this control.
Background color of the table.
The endpoint to call to retrieve data for the table. The endpoint should return data using the Out-UDTableData cmdlet.
Font color within the table.
Headers for columns in the table.
The ID of the table. This is the HTML markup ID.
Links to display on the bottom of the table. Use New-UDLink to generate a link.
The number of seconds between refreshes. The default is 5.
Allows for changing the style of the table.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the state of an element.

maml:Description.maml:para: The attributes to set. The attriubte hashtable is currently not merged so all attributes sent previously will be overridden.
Add the element to all connected clients. If you don't specify this Switch, the element will only be added to whoever is interacting with the website.
The content of the element to update. Existing content will be replace with the content specified here.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts a new dashboard based on the specified ScriptBlock with the title Groovy Dashboard on port 80.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Dashboard = New-UDDashboard -Title "Groovy Dashboard" PS C:\> Start-UDDashboard -Dashboard $Dashboard -Port 1000

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts a new dashboard based on the specified dashboard created by New-Dashboard with the title Groovy Dashboard on port 1000.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts a new dashboard with the name "MyDashboard".

maml:description.maml:para: Starts a REST API server.
Starts a REST API server. This server consists only of REST endpoints. Unlike Start-UDDashboard, this type of server has no user interface.

maml:Description.maml:para: Whether to AutoReload this REST API on changes.
Certificate for HTTPS.
Certificate file for HTTPS.
Certificate file password for HTTPS.
Disables telemetry collection.
An array of endpoints created with New-UDEndpoint.
The initial session state for endpoints of this dashboard. Use New-UDEndpointInitialization to create an object for this parameter.
Starts a REST API and stops any servers listening on that port.
The IP Address to listen on.
The name of the REST API server.
The port the REST API server listens on.
A collection of published folders. You can generate these folders with Publish-UDFolder.
This causes this cmdlet to block the terminal.
Whether to AutoReload this REST API on changes.
Certificate for HTTPS.
Certificate file for HTTPS.
Certificate file password for HTTPS.
Disables telemetry collection.

Starts a REST API and stops any servers listening on that port.
The IP Address to listen on.
The name of the REST API server.
The port the REST API server listens on.

This causes this cmdlet to block the terminal.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Starts a new REST API with a "user" endpoint that returns Adam, Sarah and Bill as a JSON array.

maml:description.maml:para: Stops a dashboard returned by Start-UDDashboard.
Stops a dashboard returned by Start-UDDashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: Name of the dashboard to stop.
Stops the dashboard by port number.
The dashboard server to stop. This is returned by Start-UDDashboard.
Name of the dashboard to stop.
Stops the dashboard by port number.
The dashboard server to stop. This is returned by Start-UDDashboard.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $DashboardServer = Start-UDDashboard -Content { New-UDDashboard {} } PS C:\> Stop-UDDashboard -Server $DashboardServer

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stops a dashboard returned by Start-UDDashboard.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Stop-UDDashboard -Name "MyDashboard"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stops the dashboard named "MyDashboard".

maml:description.maml:para: Stops a REST API server.
Stops a REST API server started with Start-UDRestApi

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the REST API server to stop.
The server object to stop. This is returned by Get-UDRestApi and Start-UDRestApi.
The name of the REST API server to stop.
The server object to stop. This is returned by Get-UDRestApi and Start-UDRestApi.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-UDRestApi | Stop-UDRestApi

dev:remarks.maml:para: Stops all running REST API servers.

maml:description.maml:para: Forces an element to update its state.
Forces an element to update its state. This only works with elements (charts, monitors, counters, elements, etc) that have used the Endpoint parameter and not the content parameter.

maml:Description.maml:para: Whether to broadcast this change to all connected clients.
The element to force to update .
Whether to broadcast this change to all connected clients.
The element to force to update .

dev:remarks.maml:para: Forces the counter to update its state when the button is clicked.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a running dashboard.
Updates a running dashboard. To be able to support this cmdlet you need to specify the UpdateToken parameter on Start-UDDashboard.

maml:Description.maml:para: Allows TLS 1.0 for the web request.
The content of the dashboard to update.
The update token for the dashboard. This is specified with Start-UDDashboard. Treat this as a password.
The URL of the running Universal Dashboard.

maml:description.maml:para: Writes a log messge to the Universal Dashboard log.
Writes a log messge to the Universal Dashboard log. This can be helpful for debugging endpoints.

maml:Description.maml:para: The message to log.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Write-UDLog -Level Debug -Message "Test message"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Writes a debug message to the Universal Dashboard log.
